Thus have I heard. Once, the Buddha was dwelling in the Trayastriá¹ƒÅ›a Heaven, under the PÄrijÄta tree,

on a lapis lazuli stone. The Buddha sat upon it and taught the Dharma to his mother. He spent the three months of summer there, together with a great assembly of bhiká¹£us. There were eight thousand bhiká¹£us, all of whom had attained arhatship, had exhausted all defilements, had perfected the supernormal faculties, and were able to accomplish their tasks;

there were seventy-two thousand bodhisattvas, who had already attained the supernormal faculties, had all attained dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s, and knew the thoughts and desires of all people, and could freely go to innumerable buddha-lands.
At that time, the Buddha was surrounded by an innumerable assembly of retinue and was teaching the Dharma for them.
At that time, among the assembly of devas, there were two devaputras:
one was named Devaputra Candra, and the other was named Devaputra Soma. They were sitting in the assembly.
Then the Moon Celestial Son rose from his seat, adjusted his robes, knelt on his right knee, joined his palms, and said to the Buddha:
If you wish to speak, I now wish to ask about it!
The Buddha said:
Ask as you wish.
Then the Moon Celestial Son joyfully spoke a verse, asking the Buddha:
For the sake of all with great compassion, pure and thick, attaining benefit;
Establishing it, attaining the Way, greatly pure, bestowing the sweet dew.
Having already attained peace for oneself, eliminating all defilements;
And being able to bring peace to all, therefore I wish to ask.
In countless eons, the practice was extremely difficult;
Giving up all possessions, giving without being content.
For the sake of all with an equal mind, equally concerned for the people;
Now, for this reason, I wish to ask the Honored One among humans!
Those who see the Buddha's body, adorned with various excellent marks,
All give rise to a joyful intention, the merit field they obtain.
Vast and boundless, immeasurable, surpassing the great ocean;
Therefore, I now wish to ask the one whose virtues are unsurpassed.
Also without a different intention, and without a different mind;
The leader among the heroes in the three realms, thoroughly understanding all thoughts.
The body's conduct is never following others;
Therefore, I now wish to ask the great wisdom of the world.
Whether there are virtues or not, praise and slander;
Whether there is fame or not, suffering and happiness.
All knowing the eight worldly matters, distinguishing and thoroughly understanding them;
Therefore, I wish to ask the one who has already left behind all fears.
Also protecting all people, guarding oneself as if no different;
Thus, without increase or decrease, the three realms are all like this!
Having kindness towards others, without doubt or resentment;
Therefore, I wish to ask, upholding the practice like the earth.
Generosity and upholding precepts, the mind is extremely pure;
Rather perish one's own life, never violate the precepts.
As the actions of body and speech, the mind is also like this!
Therefore, I wish to ask, the one who has transcended the world.
Forbearance and patience, taming the mind, standing firm and self-abnegating;
All of these are created by wisdom, seeing all places of hardship.
All good and evil, anger and resentment, one is able to endure them all;
Therefore, I wish to ask, having accomplished all that needs to be done.
The power of diligence is extremely strong, transcending all discussions;
For the sake of the world, one makes hardships, never for one's own sake.
Constantly seeking day and night, like a swift current entering the ocean;
Therefore, I wish to ask, his virtues are known to be equal to the heavens.
As for these desires, the three realms no longer act as such;
All kinds of kindness and love, all can be subdued.
The dhyÄna perfections are already complete, and the spiritual powers are also so!
Therefore, I wish to ask, the fierce hero among men.
As for this great wisdom, already liberated from the absence of joy;
The various evil things of the kalpas, all are abandoned.
If dwelling in emptiness and solitude, freely knowing all dharmas;
Therefore, I wish to ask, distinguishing from the secular and acting.
The spiritual powers, meritorious wisdom, extinguishing the unwholesome conduct;
From here reaching other realms, not praising the compassionate thoughts.
Making offerings to the buddhas, yet having no thoughts of the Buddha;
Therefore, I wish to ask, showing love for the people of the world.
At that time, all the demons came, gathering together in great numbers;
Immediately, by the power of the Dharma, the multitude of demons all destroyed themselves.
Then, having subdued the demons, he attained the Way and accomplished it;
Therefore, I wish to ask, his merit is the most supreme.
All who dwell on the ground, the golden seat emerges from the ground;
Immediately, he attained the Way, the Buddha's wisdom is immeasurable.
Then he rose and went to another place, all completely understanding the various discussions;
Therefore, I wish to ask, the supreme one among humans.
All-knowing merits and virtues, being the most honored among the honored!
Having already attained the Buddha's intention, speaking the sÅ«tras and practicing in accordance with the Dharma.
Gathering together to cross over, the guide is for all;
Therefore, I ask about the discussion, the three realms all receive grace.
Then, having praised the Buddha with a verse, the Moon Son said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
How can bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas attain the great supernatural powers and wisdom, and reach the other shore?
How can bodhisattvas attain inconceivable skillful means, and know the thoughts of others?
How can bodhisattvas know all dharmas, which are of one practice, one flavor, one entry, and one teaching?
How can they attain wisdom and freely expound it for others?
How can bodhisattvas attain the profound precepts, be without negligence, and attain the unsurpassed perfect true way without leaving the Buddha?
The questions are as such.
World-Honored One!
Please explain them.
The Buddha told the Moon Son:
Excellent, excellent!
Son of Heaven!
You wish to cultivate the TathÄgata's work;ğŸ”½You wish to don the great saá¹ƒghÄá¹­Ä«;
You wish to enter the great battle and become a great guide;
Wishing to liberate all;
Wishing to make a great ship;
Wishing to turn the great Dharma wheel;
Wishing to make great offerings;
Wishing to make a great Dharma body;ğŸ”½Wishing to make a great Dharma rain;
Wishing to light the great Dharma fire;ğŸ”½Wishing to beat the great Dharma drum;
Wishing to raise the great Dharma banner;
Wishing to speak of the great Dharma realm;ğŸ”½Wishing to emit the great Dharma sound;
Wishing to cultivate the great Dharma;
Wishing to manifest the great Dharma wisdom;
Wishing to sever wrong views and sacrifices;
Wishing to establish and fulfill the great sacrifice, wishing to make such innumerable appearances, and for the sake of all, to hold this discussion and ask the TathÄgata.
The Buddha said to the celestial son:
Listen carefully, listen carefully!
Contemplate it well!
I will explain it for you.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva attains the great wisdom and reaches the profound and subtle precepts, and thus attains the unsurpassed true path and becomes the perfect supreme enlightenment.
Thus, celestial son!
Listen to what the World-Honored Buddha says.
Then the Moon Son and the great assembly joined palms to receive the teaching and listen.
The Buddha said to the Son:
Bodhisattvas have four practices that enable them to attain the great universal dhÄraá¹‡Ä«.
What are the four?
First, knowing the appearance of all dharmas without increase or decrease.
Second, seeking all dharmas.
Third, all dharmas are inexhaustible, attaining concentration, peace, and the realization of learning.
Fourth, not seeing any dharmas apart from the nature of dharmas, not hoping for or viewing other dharma realms.
These are the four practices.
What do you think, Son?
What is knowing the appearance of dharmas?
Knowing the past is also empty, the future is also empty, and the present is also empty. All that exists is also empty, like emptiness.
In this way, Son!
Seeking emptiness while sitting in samÄdhi for a long time, each not knowing where it is, this is called complete understanding;
Thus, Heavenly Son!
Knowing this place is called discrimination and understanding.

Understanding all decisions, then holding and turning to teach each other, this place, knowing the place, establishing the place, discriminating the place, such a place, discussing the place, passing on to each other, this is called merit.
Thus, Heavenly Son!
How does one attain all dharmas?
Dharmas also do not think of me, and I also do not think of dharmas. When dharmas arise, then they arise; when dharmas abide, then they abide.
Heavenly Son!

All dharmas are like this. Mine and not mine are all already non-existent. For bodhisattvas like this, it is turning forward. For those who turn forward, they then no longer delight in the place of arising and ceasing.
Why is it so?
Because all that exists is non-existent.
In non-existence, one contemplates other dharmas. Although contemplating, one does not learn anything from other dharmas;
Nor is there anything to be said;
Nor is there anything to abide in. Although one illuminates other dharmas greatly, one does not do so for the sake of the dharmas, nor does one learn [anything from them].
Thus, Heavenly Son!
How does a bodhisattva know that all dharmas are equal to space?
The mind, Heavenly Son!
Creates the three realms. Thus, Heavenly Son!
The mind has no form, is invisible, has no place of rest, and is unknowable. The mind and mental factors are like an illusion, and the mind is also unobtainable when sought.
Thus, the mind and mental factors, when the mind is sought, are unobtainable. This mind is also unknowable. Thus, the mind and all dharmas are unobtainable.

Furthermore, they are unobtainable and nonexistent. When dharmas are examined, they are like transformations and like shadows. Having known all dharmas in this way, one transcends. Having already transcended, one naturally knows all that is not learned. Thus, one knows that all dharmas are equal to space.
Thus, Heavenly Son!
Just as space is invisible, has no arising, and no growth, one should know that all dharmas are also like this!
In this way, space is also like space, tranquil and pure, and in this way, all dharmas are also tranquil and pure.
In this way, son of heaven!
How should a bodhisattva know the nature of all dharmas?
In this way, son of heaven!
A bodhisattva should study in this way, not seeing any dharmas, and not being able to obtain them.
The eye does not see the ear, and the ear does not know the ear; the ear does not see the eye, and the eye does not know the eye;
the nose does not see the tongue, and the tongue does not know the tongue; the tongue does not see the nose, and the nose does not know the nose;
the nose does not see the body, and the body does not know the body; the body does not see the mind, and the mind does not know the mind.
If the nature of all dharmas, whether in practice or at rest, is to be known equally, where is the nature of dharmas located?
In this way, the eye sees and knows the distinctions in phenomena, not saying 'is' or 'is not', and also not following them. For this reason, one can know the abode of permanence;
And also not causing harm to phenomena.
Why is it so?
Because externally it does not enter, and internally it is not received. Regarding harm and non-harm, one should know and see in this way;
And also not causing birth or abiding in phenomena, abiding in this way is to see all.
In this way, Heavenly Son!
This is the nature of phenomena.

In this way, the nature of phenomena neither arises nor ceases. In this place, there is nothing, yet it manifests all phenomena. Abiding in the unborn and unarisen, this is the abode of cessation. In this way, one carefully observes as one sees with the eyes. Wisdom is also like this!
And also not in the nature of phenomena, and also without liberation, yet flourishing and abiding. Those phenomena and the nature of phenomena are complete.
In this way, Heavenly Son!
This is the four practices.
The bodhisattva attains the power of great supernatural knowledge and wisdom, and attains the utmost perfection.
Thus, Heavenly Son!
What is supernatural power?
What is wisdom?
Heavenly Son!
Supernatural power is:
Knowing the essential meaning of all dharmas, and understanding each and every one of those knowledges. Therefore, Heavenly Son!
It is called supernatural power.
Knowing oneself and one's name in all dharmas, Heavenly Son!
The self is not arrogant, this is the wisdom of the Dharma.
Thus, Heavenly Son!
The bodhisattva, for this reason, quickly attains the power of great supernatural knowledge and wisdom, and is not weary in his aspirations.
Why is it so?
Because he wishes to fulfill his aspirations.
Such wisdom, Heavenly Son!

Surpasses the human eye, and attains the pure heavenly eye, seeing countless, innumerable billions and trillions of buddha-lands in the ten directions, seeing the buddhas, world-honored ones, and their assemblies of disciples in those lands;
With the divine ear, they hear all the Dharma spoken by the buddhas and world-honored ones, and they hear and know it all.

In all the buddha-lands, they know the superior, middling, and inferior matters of all the people who are learning and have learned, and they are able to travel to all the buddha-lands with their spiritual powers. They know all the past lives from innumerable eons ago, and they know the thoughts and intentions of all people and the origins and ends of their rebirths. They uphold this wisdom and realize it for themselves, and they are then able to expound the Dharma for all.
Such wisdom, Heavenly Son!

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva attains omniscience, abides in all that the Buddha does, quickly attains the Dharma of the buddhas, and accomplishes the unsurpassed true path of perfect supreme enlightenment.
At that time, the Buddha spoke a verse, saying:
Herein, the great spiritual powers are all already fulfilled;
The skillful means that are employed are seen to be the marks of merit.
And all phenomena are thoroughly understood;ğŸ”½The profound virtues of pure precepts
Are also all attained through this.ğŸ”½For this reason, all phenomena
Are thoroughly understood;ğŸ”½One will never in this practice
Think of transgression.ğŸ”½All that exists
Is also like this!ğŸ”½It is like empty space,
With no difference in the meaning of the Dharma.ğŸ”½In this true and real Dharma,
One then gets to see the Dharma;ğŸ”½Without doubting the Dharma realm,
One understands through this.ğŸ”½Not by merely practicing the Dharma
Can one fully understand;ğŸ”½One must discern and comprehend
In order to attain spiritual powers.ğŸ”½All past phenomena
Are all like empty space;ğŸ”½All future phenomena
Are also non-existent.ğŸ”½All present phenomena
Are also equal to empty space;
All that is seen is the same.
The dharmas of the three times are all like empty space;
They are not what I possess, nor are they not what I possess.
By knowing one's own birth, all are also like this!
Thus, all that is seen becomes the attainment of faith.
Knowing this, the merits are no longer the same;
For all, the Dharma is taught, and yet the Dharma is not conceived of.
There is neither anger nor resentment, nor is it said to be right or wrong;
There is also no doubt, and there is also no awareness.
For one who is already like this, the dharmas are established;
In these practices, there are none that remain.
In this Dharma without remainder, all dharmas are just so!
There is also nothing seen in the different dharmas.
In this way, one does not give rise to [the notion of] existence, nor does one give rise to [the notion of] non-existence;
In this, there is no entry, nor is there anything to be attained.
One then attains virtue, and expounds the Dharma for all;
Universally expounding the meaning of the Dharma, one has no thoughts of the Way.
One's mind in the three realms is already extremely delightful;
If the mind is like this, it is utterly invisible.
Formless like a shadow, its image is also like this!
If one seeks for the Dharma, one's mind is already still.
If there is a desire to seek out the mind in this Dharma,
The Dharma does not see the mind, and the mind does not see the Dharma.
If one's mind is like this, the mind seeks out the mind;
If the mind is already like this, one has already seen all habits.
All dharmas are also like this!
There is no one who can understand the Dharma;ğŸ”½...
All thoughts and ideas cannot obstruct it.
All incomplete dharmas I shall accomplish them all;
Those dharmas are like empty space, always abiding without increase or decrease.
Just like empty space, what is born has no existence;
Those who are already like this see all dharmas.
Also, in empty space there is nothing to be done;
This is called good, and all dharmas are also like this!
The eyes also do not see the ears, and the ears also do not see the eyes;
The tongue also does not see the nose, and the nose also does not see the tongue.
The body also does not see the mind, and the mind also does not see the body;
Each is in its own place, and in each place they do not see each other.
If one hears from others, or knows for oneself,
In this way one is able to expound the dharma realm for others.
And thus it is all equally empty;ğŸ”½The six sense objects do not know me,
And I also do not know the sense objects.ğŸ”½Thus all of this is completely known,
The matters of the studied dharmas;ğŸ”½Having studied like this,
One's wisdom is immeasurable.
One completely sees the innumerable koá¹­is of buddhas in the ten directions,
And hears the honored ones speaking the Dharma to their assemblies of disciples.ğŸ”½Those who, with regard to this Dharma,
Speak it extensively for others,ğŸ”½With regard to this immeasurable wisdom,
It is already extremely pure.ğŸ”½Well speaking the virtues of the precepts,
And hearing them completely;ğŸ”½Understanding all the discussions,ğŸ”½Distinguishing them and fulfilling them all.ğŸ”½Completely knowing all,
The thoughts in their minds;ğŸ”½Then using the power of spiritual penetrations,
Wandering to koá¹­is of lands.ğŸ”½For innumerable koá¹­is of thousands of myriads of kalpas,
As numerous as the sands of the Ganges River;
They all see and understand.ğŸ”½And then they engage in these practices,
Having attained the five supernormal knowledges;ğŸ”½Then they rely on this to approach,
The peaceful and unsurpassed enlightenment.ğŸ”½The abodes of the Buddha,
They all abide in them;ğŸ”½Those who have not yet attained the Way,
Should seek its principles in the Way.ğŸ”½Then they view all dharmas,
All empty, with nothing to see;ğŸ”½They then give rise to a joyful mind,
With delight surpassing all others.ğŸ”½All the hosts of MÄras,
Cannot move a single hair of theirs;ğŸ”½Swiftly attaining perfect enlightenment,
The unsurpassed and most honored one.
Son of Heaven!
There are also four kinds of dharmas by which Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas attain the merit of inconceivable skillful means.
What are the four?
First, attaining the merit of wisdom from past lives.

Second, for those who have nothing to rely on, those who are cold and frozen, those who are suffering, those who are in pain, and those who are sorrowful, if one sees such a multitude of suffering and distress, one should immediately give rise to the intention to joyfully rescue them, and teach them all to seek the Buddha's path.

Third, using all dharmas to uphold the Buddha's intention in relation to all, upholding the merits and blessings of one's own past virtues from the distant past, and further upholding the merits and blessings of all past buddhas to encourage and assist them, causing them all to be liberated from worries and suffering, to be pardoned and released, and to completely uphold these merits and virtues to offer to all those who are in hardship and difficulty.
Fourth, one has never given rise to the intention to not fulfill all wishes;
one has also never given rise to the intention to let people slip and not reach the path;
one has also never caused all to not reach the path.
Just as my mind wishes to reach the path, the path also welcomes my mind. In this way, wisdom immediately welcomes the mind, and the mind immediately attains the wisdom of the path.
They uphold skillful means, increasing merit and virtue without destroying the dharma realm;
In the conceivable dharmas, their learning is insatiable;

They are also insatiable with regard to all merits and virtues, thus creating merits and virtues without satiation, without losing anything in their mental dharmas, and their minds do not lose anything with regard to merits and virtues.
They always practice giving, their minds pure and without expectation;
They always uphold precepts without deficiency;ğŸ”½In the power of patience, they do not waver;
They increase in diligence without being lazy;
In dhyÄna samÄdhi, they are not distracted;
With wisdom, they are not foolish.

They always make offerings to all without craving, repay kindness with kindness without worry, contemplate birth without attaining non-birth, worry about the dharmas they speak, and worry about causing all to be liberated.
Son of Heaven!
The bodhisattva practices like this!
Those who know small blessings, through skillful means, their accomplishments are innumerable and immeasurable.
Thus, Heavenly Son!
Bodhisattvas attain innumerable wisdoms in all these dharmas, and there is nothing in the dharmas that they do not know or do not understand.
Why is it so?
Heavenly Son!
All dharmas are empty, without thought, and without desire.
Thus, emptiness is innumerable, and the mind attains innumerable small merits, and through skillful means, their accomplishments are innumerable and immeasurable.
Why is it so?
Thus, the path is immeasurable, and the mind is also like this!

Thus, practice is immeasurable, and immeasurable dharmas without boundaries follow immeasurable dharmas without boundaries. Thus, the Dharma of the Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, is also without boundaries and immeasurable.
Furthermore, Heavenly Son!

The bodhisattva, with skillful means, surpasses all practices, and having surpassed them, he gives to those who delight in giving, seeks for those who delight in seeking, and expounds the Dharma to liberate them.
Moreover, Heavenly Son!
If the bodhisattva is like this, he attains innumerable incalculable practiced dharmas, and then is fully endowed with giving, morality, patience, vigor, meditation, and wisdom.
He has no contemptuous mind towards suffering people;
He does not violate the precepts, but benefits others through the precepts;
He is patient with all people, enduring their scolding and contempt;
He combines all wholesome virtues in his vigor;
He attains various concentrations in meditation;
And in wisdom, he is unobstructed.
Moreover, Heavenly Son!
The bodhisattva, with skillful means, manifests practices among the disciples and teaches them according to their Dharma, while internally having no expectations;
he manifests practices among the pratyekabuddhas and teaches them according to their Dharma, while internally having no expectations.
In this way, Heavenly Son!
The bodhisattva, through these four dharmas, attains inconceivable skillful wisdom.
At that time, the Buddha spoke a verse, saying:
There are two kinds of suffering, namely that of oneself and that of others;
One extinguishes one's own suffering, and is also able to extinguish the other's.
One is concerned for all people, causing their minds to understand the affairs of the Way;
One's mind is also like this towards the Dharma, causing all to understand the one principle.
One uses blessings for all people, practicing diligently through the three time periods;
The blessings practiced by the buddhas, one encourages and assists them all.
With these meritorious blessings, one offers them to all;
In all mental states, may they quickly attain the wisdom of the Buddha.
May all who arouse the intention study the true path;
Do not seek anything else in the mind.
The mind does not hope for the path, and it cannot be seen even when looked at;
The characteristics of the mind are like this, and the characteristics of the mind are also the same!
The Dharma is equal, and so is equality, and there is no self in me;
Know for oneself and see the merits, and increase the pure merits.
There is no increase in the body, and the Dharma realm is difficult to conceive;
Always abiding in the place of the path, this is seeking the Buddha!
The mind has never thought of using its own greatness to benefit itself;
The mind always abides in the path, diligently practicing without slacking off.
Generous giving without weariness, always firmly guarding the precepts;
Forbearance is also like this, not creating the faculties of others.
Practicing diligently day by day, always contemplating the emptiness of the body;
In meditation, tranquil and still, with wisdom able to liberate all.
Nurturing and protecting all, one's actions like a lotus flower;
Generous giving and upholding purity, not expecting anything from others.
Always aspiring to seek the Buddha's wisdom, fully understanding all dharmas;
Comprehending and practicing all dharmas, one's wisdom is inconceivable.
Teaching the Dharma for all, without any obstruction;
If there is one who accords with this practice, they are a bodhisattva!
All fully understand emptiness, giving a little with immeasurable rewards;
Not conceiving of existence or non-existence, the mind never indulges.
Fully knowing all practices, liberating according to one's vows;
Generously giving according to one's wishes, teaching the Dharma and transforming through flourishing.
Having given without regret, not violating the precepts;
Patience, vigor, meditation, and wisdom, without arrogance.
Generosity, upholding precepts, patience, and vigor;
In meditation and samÄdhi, wisdom and generosity are subdued and regulated.
In the practices of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas,
Liberating according to their inclinations, not following internally.
Firmly abiding in this Dharma, bodhisattvas are unattached;
Skillful wisdom is inconceivable, swiftly attaining the subduing of all.
Moreover, Heavenly Son!
Bodhisattvas, with four things, all dharmas are of one taste, of one entrance, of one explanation, and their wisdom all penetrates the various discourses.
What are the four?
Thus, Heavenly Son!

Bodhisattvas, in the dharma realm, attain the merit of all wisdom, without destruction, and believe that all dharmas are empty, and also do not say in the dharma realm, 'This is done by me' or 'This is not done by me.'
Why is it so?
What I do is also not, and what is not done by me is all not.
Why is it so?
Destroying all that should not be practiced, one then attains the knowledge of all dharmas.
Heavenly son!

These are the four dharmas by which bodhisattvas know that all dharmas are of one taste, of one entry, and of one teaching. Such knowledge is the complete understanding of the various intellectual discussions.
Knowing thus, seeing thus;
Whether in the mundane or the supramundane, one then turns the Dharma wheel with compassion;
If there is practice, one practices it;
If there is kindness, one is kind;

If there are those who stand, they stand with the Dharma, they turn the great compassion of the Dharma, and do not speak of the honored ones among the various dharmas, this is being lowly. They do not enter the Dharma, nor do they practice the Dharma, nor do they see anything to be practiced in the various dharmas. Knowing the Dharma of ordinary people, they again practice the Dharma of ordinary people, and in the Dharma of ordinary people there is nothing to be exalted or debased. In this way, the Dharma of destroying habits is also like this, and then extensively explains all dharmas.
In the Dharma realm, nothing is seen to be destroyed.
Why is it so?
It is to attain the acceptance of the one, to accept emptiness.
In the acceptance of emptiness, one does not doubt. As with one entrance, the entrances to all dharmas are also like this!
As with the entrance of non-arising, Heavenly Son!
In this way, the bodhisattva approaches the unsurpassed true path of the Buddha, the World-Honored One, and also does not think of approaching the Buddha or not approaching the Buddha.
Why is it so?
Also, one does not see the destruction of a single thing.
Why is it so?
Also, one does not see the person as different;
Also, one does not see the path as different;
Also, one does not see the person;
Also, one does not see the path.
At that time, the Buddha spoke a verse, saying:
Do not speak of right and wrong within the Dharma realm, and do not destroy anything within the Dharma realm.
The Dharma realm is like this, and all are like this. If one does not contemplate, one does not understand the meaning.
Having already believed in the emptiness of all dharmas, the six sense bases have long been united with emptiness.
All dharmas are tranquil and attain mastery. If one place is empty, all are so.
Within the Dharma, there is no seeing and no one who sees, and there is also no self that can be obtained.
If I can learn to be like this, then I will be able to clearly understand the meaning of the path.
Practice should accord with tranquility and attain the treasury of emptiness. Stillness follows along with all dharmas.
Know that all dharmas are tranquil, and within this tranquil purity, there is nothing unacceptable.
Knowing all worldly dharmas, one has no doubts or hesitation,
One's vows are unbroken, one hears the Dharma and always contemplates without indolence or arrogance.
In countless, incalculable ways, one's body does not see itself,
Transmigrating through the five paths, one does not see the Dharma, only ordinary people and arhats can know it.
What ordinary people practice is always spoken of, such matters are the Dharma of arhats,
Neither exalted nor low, tranquil and unaccepting, only then can one know.
Knowing all the numbers of dharmas, one does not destroy the Dharma realm,
Patience is no different from empty space, all dharmas are like this!
Patience is like empty space, with nothing to think of, all dharmas enter a single wisdom,
Like birth from nothing, not giving rise to practice, practicing the path in this way is not difficult.
Thus, cultivating the immeasurable path, one should be mindful without indolence,
If I or others are like this in the Dharma, then the path of enlightenment is realized without attainment.
Son of Heaven!
Bodhisattvas have four practices that enable them to be heedful in the profound precepts.
What are the four?
Thus, Son of Heaven!
Bodhisattvas contemplate themselves, what is called precepts?
Thus, they observe their own conduct, knowing that the conduct of the body is good, the speech is good, and the thoughts are good, this is called precepts.
What is meant by the conduct of the body, the speech, and the thoughts?
Not committing bodily acts, not killing, not stealing, not engaging in sexual misconduct, this is called the good conduct of the body.
What is meant by the good speech?
Not speaking harshly, not engaging in divisive speech, not lying, not engaging in frivolous speech, this is the good speech.
What is meant by the good thoughts?
Not being jealous, not being angry, and not having wrong views are called the good thoughts in the mind.
In this way, one observes oneself and sees that because of this, one fully obtains the same as the actions of body, speech, and mind, and there is no one who can fully expound its virtues;
it is also not blue, yellow, red, white, or crimson, and it is not apart from form;
it is also not something that can be cognized by eye-consciousness.
In this way, it is also not something that can be cognized by discriminating with mental consciousness.
Why is this?
In this way, it is unborn and has nothing that is born, and in arising, it has nothing that arises.

In this way, being unborn and having nothing that is born, and not arising and having nothing that arises, one then attains the virtue of being able to fully expound, at this time the mind abides peacefully and does not waver, in this way it does not encounter anything that can be fully expounded, in this way there is nothing that can be fully expounded, and one also does not say oneself that one can do this, speak this, or practice this, and the mind is also unobservable.
In this way, the mind is also said to be unobservable.
In this way, Your Majesty!
The bodhisattva attains the virtue of the profound precepts.
Furthermore, Your Majesty!

The bodhisattva attains the knowledge of the body that is free from views, knowing that in what is seen there is nothing to be produced. Whether it is good or bad precepts, there is nothing to be done.
Furthermore, Your Majesty!

The bodhisattva attains the profound Dharma that is to be entered and abides in it. He makes such offerings, and practices all the profound activities that are to be learned. He practices all the activities of all vehicles. This is called precepts.
In this way, the practice is neither to deceive oneself nor to deceive others. This is called the profound precepts.
Furthermore, Your Majesty!
The bodhisattva attains the precepts that are not violated, not deficient, and not lost.
How is it that the bodhisattva does not violate the precepts, does not have deficient precepts, and does not lose the precepts?
Your Majesty!
Those who can protect themselves can then protect the precepts.
Heavenly son!
Those who know themselves can then know the precepts, not belittle the precepts, not be deficient in what they learn, and not lose the precepts. Because of this, they do not lose the precepts.
They know all the dharmas of others.
Who are others?
Where am I?
They do not despise others either!
Heavenly son!
Because of this, they can liberate all people.
Heavenly son!
These are the four dharmas.
Bodhisattvas attain the profound precepts and are not negligent.
The Buddha then spoke a verse, saying:
The actions of body, speech, and mind are pure and pure according to the Dharma;
Their practice surpasses precious treasures - this precept should be observed by bodhisattvas!
These ten are unsurpassed - the wise bodhisattva upholds and protects them!
Body, speech, and mind are not deficient - this precept is the wisest.
Non-action also does not arise, within arising there is no arising;
Without seeds, without a place to abide, without wisdom, how can one attain?
Not meeting, not creating precepts, the eyes cannot see what is invisible;
Not the ears, nose, mouth, not the body or mind's perception.
Not creating the six sense faculties, the place of abiding is also non-existent;
This precept is extremely pure, the precept also has no place of abiding.
Upholding the precepts without negligence, within the precepts there is no thought of self;
Protecting the precepts without the thought of precepts, by this one attains the profound precepts.
Herein, seeing bodily actions, departing from all views;
Not following the place of views, within the precepts there is no thought.
Like the precepts entering the profound Dharma, all practices are completed;
Extinguishing existence, one is then able to protect, within the precepts there is no different thought.
Where there is self, there are precepts; where there is no self, there are also no precepts;

The precept of emptiness and tranquility is without time, the precept of tranquility does not contemplate.
The precept of non-deficiency is unsurpassed, one does not exalt oneself in the precepts;
The precept also has no thought of self, this is then the profound precept.
In the precepts one is very courageous, not doing what is unwholesome;
One precept is endowed with many practices, all dharmas cannot be obtained.
Having thoughts of precepts is delusion, saying that without precepts one guards precepts;
This is the result of the destruction of precepts, not being liberated from the five paths.
Far removed from all views, what is mine is all unseen;
Precepts also have nothing to see, not fearing the five paths.
Seeing what is not seen as seeing, not increasing unwholesome precepts;
With regard to self there is no illness, practicing precepts all see.
